site_title: The Best Croissants in NYC - Eater NY

description: The components of the so-called Greek slice are deceptively simple; a very crisp square crust that crackles rather than squishes, with perhaps a pinch of sugar in the dough, assorted olives both black and green, the collection varying by day, sweet baby plum tomatoes cut in half, plain tomato sauce, basil leaves, and maybe the occasional mince of fresh garlic. You won’t miss the cheese in the novel, crave-able slice.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 1524 Myrtle Ave (btwn Gates Ave & Linden St), Brooklyn, NY 11237
description: This Bushwick bakery from Gus Reckel opened in 2016 and still turns out terrific neighborhood favorites. A bit of the bread starter goes into the croissant dough, which then are baked into a handful of flavors: chocolate, beet chocolate, almond meringue, sausage, raisin, pistachio, ham and cheese, and jalapeno cheddar, depending on the day, for around $6.50.
site_title: The Best Croissants in NYC - Eater NY

description: I like pizzerias squished into tiny spaces, where the ovens dominated the visual landscape and a single employee serves as pie wrangler and cashier. Just down the block from an important subway stop, Village Pizza is just such a place, with a surprisingly large collection of slices for its cramped premises. The Buffalo chicken is one the best, featuring a cut-up chicken cutlet and tart sauce that delivers a spicy and vinegary tang. Some say this slice was invented by pizzerias trying to get in on the football-party delivery action without actually doing wings.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Husband-and-wife team Gautier and Ashley Coiffard opened this Brooklyn Heights spot in spring 2022, and there are still lines on weekend mornings for the warm croissants and their viral petite croissant cereal. Beyond the classic croissants, there are chocolate, almond, raspberry, and one topped with everything seasoning. There’s a space to sit upstairs, as well as a few tables dotted on the sidewalk outside.
site_title: The Best Croissants in NYC - Eater NY

description: The stylish pizzeria (the name means “Little Moon”) is on the verge of becoming an actual restaurant, but the emphasis remains staunchly on some excellent pies, with a sauce perhaps a little sweeter than usual. The margherita is a round, thin-crust pie with fresh mozzarella and crushed tomatoes here and there, creating a prodigious mouth wallop. A larger than usual roster of apps, subs, hamburgers, heros, and cheesesteaks provide enhanced dinner options.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Of course the epitome of the caramelized school is Cobble Hill’s Bien Cuit, where the slogan on the sign out front reads “pastry well done.” Though it looks like a wooden paperweight, there could hardly be a more carefully turned-out croissant — the pastry leaves well defined, the thing as symmetrical as a football — and when you nip off the end, the inside is just as perfect. They may be drier than you’d like.
site_title: The Best Croissants in NYC - Eater NY

description: Located on the northern reaches of Manhattan Avenue, Triangolo is one of Greenpoint’s most distinguished neighborhood parlors. An order on a recent visit was an extra-thick slice with sauce and cheese, dotted with bacon, pepperoni, and ground beef. The cheese and spinach stromboli, with a particularly crisp crust, was also exemplary. Dig the lettering on the neon sign outside, and don’t miss the cryptic Steven Seagal shrine.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Otway offers a classic selection of croissants among baked goods: traditional ($4.50) to chocolate, and ham and cheese among them. The breads are standout, too.
site_title: The Best Croissants in NYC - Eater NY

description: King of the Manhattan neighborhood pizza parlor, Joe’s offers a slice magnificent in its plainness, appreciated by generations of New Yorkers and visitors. No frou-frou here, just a well-pureed sauce and just enough cheese — but not too much — and one of the city’s most perfect crusts. On the other hand, for just a bit more you can get the fresh mozzarella slice, with little annealed gobs of cheese. The best-selling slice, according to a counter guy I talked to, is the pepperoni. Miraculously, new branches of this place near Union Square, Times Square, and in Williamsburg have not diminished its brilliance.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Yes, the swells head further down Greenpoint Avenue for Paulie Gee’s, a wood-oven place with some weird and sometimes spectacular pies. Franklin is conveniently located just across the street from the historic Pencil Factory bar, so that you can see beer fans knocking off a slice or two before scampering across the street. Featuring both ricotta and mozzarella, the broccoli slice is a particular fave, and the drinkers all know that one constitutes a perfectly balanced meal.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 83 Saint Marks Pl (at 1st Ave.), New York, NY 10003
description: Generations of rock musicians, poets, and painters have cheaply feasted — often late into the night — at Stromboli, located at the crossroads of St. Marks and First Avenue in the East Village. The crust is thin, the deep red sauce with more than a touch of sweetness, and the cheese moderately applied, and late in evening, clubgoers mill around on the sidewalks gobbling down their slices.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 177 Spring St (at Thompson St), New York, NY 10012
description: Famous Ben’s was founded in 1979 and remains Soho’s bastion of the Sicilian slice. Most interesting, perhaps, are the versions of the classic square pie that pre-date the cheese-and-tomato-sauced square so famous at nearly every neighborhood pizza parlor. The Palermo sliced (aka sfincione) is topped with onions, tomato sauce, and bread crumbs — but no cheese.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Proving that old-style neighborhood pizzerias are not a bygone phenomenon, Rosalia’s opened not long ago in Forest Hills, with the same owner as Luzzo’s in the East Village and bygone Gansevoort Market. You can tell the proprietor is a Staten Islander the minute you bite into the spinach and artichoke slice, with little hills of melting ricotta, and a soupy greenish sauce. In Staten Island, the semi-liquid slice is king.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: There are now multiple locations of this 1987 pizzeria that seeks to incorporate Cajun influences into the pizza canon. The East Village location is pretty much the flagship these days, and the slices are still named after late-20th century
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 375 Canal St (at West Broadway), New York, NY 10013
description: — a first Manhattan branch of an Avenue X pizzeria that attracted
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This modest neighborhood spot has an attached dining room, which means even at peak hours you don’t have to eat your slice standing up. The slogan is, “Where every slice is a journey to Italy,” though this is about as American as pizza gets. The classic margherita is really just an amped up cheese slice, but it is delicious with its fresh mozzarella and sprightly tomato sauce.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This downtown Forest Hills fixture goes all the way back to 1960, but underwent a hiatus early in this century. Now it’s back and better than ever, offering a windowed dining room and the usual rich profusion of slice choices. A fave is the grandma slice: a crisp, square crust with an impressive slab of mozzarella, a slice of fresh tomato, and strips of roasted red pepper, making for an unusual slice that tastes like an Italian street fair.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 113 Mulberry St (btwn Canal and Hester), New York, NY 10013
description: This newish Little Italy pizzeria more or less presents itself as a cocktail lounge — yet it serves slices and behaves in many respects as a neighborhood pizzeria. The Neapolitan slices tend to be a bit heavy and browned, and often display atypical toppings.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This revolutionary neighborhood pizzeria deep in the Lower East Side is a game changer where slices are concerned. For a traditional pizzeria, more care is taken than usual — the flour is freshly milled in the basement, for Pete’s sake. Long lines form, and slices are richer and thinner crusted than most. Sicilian slices and grandma slices are also available. This is a unique and exciting neighborhood pizzeria.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Holding down an incredibly expensive corner location in Tribeca, Dona Bella ("Beautiful Lady") puts an almost surreal amount of energy into its eye-socking window display. The crusts on the Neapolitan slices are a little thicker than usual, the toppings applied with a thick hand. A case in point is the wonderful mushroom slice, to which a great heap of ‘shrooms has been applied, and plenty of cheese, too. The round fresh mozzarella pie is also great, with big splotches of sweet tomato sauce.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This 1967 neighborhood pizzeria is more elegant than most, with views out the big picture windows (which open in fine weather) and good wine and beer served, too. The eggplant slice features crisp, crumbed slices of vegetable, hillocks of ricotta, and a thin crust that invites you to eat the thing with a knife and fork. And nobody will laugh at you if you do.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: All Little Italy franchises are not the same. In fact, some are superb while others awful, with doughy crusts and lifeless tomato sauces. The City Hall branch is one of the great ones, and you can tell the minute you step inside and see the elated diners. A favorite slice is the carbonara, which features two kinds of cheese along with shards of prosciutto, making it one of the city’s few pies to utilize that cold-cut cooked.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: There’s a new branch drawing lines at lunchtime in the West Village, but I still prefer the original in the shadow of the BQE in an obscure corner of Williamsburg. If you can get a cheese slice right out of the oven, grab it! Otherwise, slices are prepared ahead, adding, say burrata to a once-baked slice. (Inn some ways, it’s perhaps a signature topping.)  Italian pastries are also excellent here.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Open in the shadow of the M and J tracks, this parlor is young in pizzeria years, but excels at all the classic pies and hero sandwiches. Some of the best things on the menu, though, show a Latin bent. For example, the miniature pie called an onion pizzette is about as close as you can get to a real Buenos Aires fugazetta. Other favorites include a spinach-ricotta slice that seems positively healthy, and an idiosyncratic take on a hot dog, wrapping it in pizza dough with melted cheese. Delicious!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: How does a simple independent slice joint stay in business in the Wall Street area? By serving some of the best pizza in town in a somewhat shabby and abject location a few steps below street level. Nevertheless, this is a frequently recommended favorite among brokers, clerks, digital journalists, and non-profit wonks who labor in the neighborhood. The fresh mozzarella slice is especially enticing, with splotches of sweet herby tomato sauce, great mozzarella that doesn’t go all soggy, and a memorably crisp, browned crust.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This antediluvian Bushwick pizzeria that resides above the Dekalb stop on the L dates back to the days when this was an Italian neighborhood and its sausage roll was fabled. In terms of pizza, go for the Sicilian slice. It's thick and square and brown as a beetle, with little rivulets of sauce and cheese and a generous sprinkling of dried Romano for extra saltiness and flavor. It's worth traveling from another borough to try!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This pizzeria, shuttered for nearly a year by
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Since the 1970s, when Bushwick was still an Italian stronghold, Tony’s Pizza has been turning out near-perfect pies on Knickerbocker Avenue, a stone’s throw from Maria Hernandez Park. The slice is austere in its structure: the crust pale and thinner than most, but crisp; the sauce mild and only slightly sweet; the better-than-average cheese strewn with a generous hand. Devotees also extol the hot hero sandwiches, potato-lovers pie, and fried calamari.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located in an obscure corner of downtown Brooklyn, Little Pizza is the cutest pizzeria around, with outdoor seating along the sidewalk and a pretty flower-tile motif inside. The thin-crust slices often stray from the typical, with sausage, tomatoes, hot cherry peppers, and mozzarella, and the margherita adds a good quantity of pecorino to the usual fresh mozzarella.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: What pizza parlor boasts outdoor seating in the back? This one in downtown Brooklyn does, and also a large dining room perfect for accommodating lunchtime crowds. The supreme slice is the one to get, with an unusually thin crust for a fresh mozzarella slice, browned more than most and hence crisp. The cheese is cooked a little more, too. This is an atypical take on a classic slice, and six or seven more slices are commonly available at any given time. Especially if you’re a plain-cheese orderer, ask for a lime to spray over the slice.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Making fun of the Famous Ray's and its imitators, Not Ray's is a neighborhood pizza parlor in a memorable, wedge-shaped space right on Fulton Street. The slice has a narrow cornicione, the cheese is modestly applied, and the tomato sauce piquant and somewhat sweet. The slice is a little gloppier than usual and a molten cheese-sauce hybrid spills over the sides. Dying for novelty? Try the Buffalo chicken or Caesar salad pies.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Ocean Hill establishment is a branch of a long-running Canarsie pizzeria that’s been in the D’Arpa family since 1968, now being run by a third generation. Like the sign outside says, the mini-chain’s specialty is the Sicilian slice, and you’ve never tasted better. The bread is thick and bouncy, but paradoxically light-textured, and the sauce in the typical Sicilian style is a little on the sweet side. In addition, there’s a strong taste of oregano, which may or may not be due to the Greek origin of many Sicilians. Other specialties include a delicious, sesame-seeded ground beef stromboli, pepperoni pinwheels, and meatball rolls.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 192 Union St (at Henry St), Brooklyn, NY 11231
description: The rarest of the pizza slice types in the city are those that come from old-fashioned Italian bakeries like Mazzola. It recently moved around the corner into newer digs, but that didn’t interfere with the excellence of its square bakery pies. Thin for a Sicilian slice, these taste of freshly baked bread, the tomato sauce is on the sweet side, and there is no stinting on the cheese. One is a meal, and extra points if you get a slice from a pie just out of the oven.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The pizzas here are damn good, with a slightly thicker crust than usual, and some fairly creative toppings. The margarita slice is memorable, pooled with fresh mozzarella and dotted with herbs, while the lasagna slice mimics that casserole with an insane amount of delicately seasoned ground beef and wads of fresh ricotta.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Champion is a mini-chain with a newish branch in Bed-Stuy. Sold by the slice, most of the pizzas are square, the crusts relatively thin, and done to a dark brown. Toppings are innovative, too, including one slice that features alternate bands of green pesto and red tomato sauce, like a Morris Lewis painting in the Museum of Modern Art.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This lively pizzeria with some nifty murals has been a mainstay of 5th Avenue in the Slope since 1987. The regular slice boasts a thicker and crisper crust than usual, and many patrons go for the extensive collection of novelties — such as the Buffalo chicken slice, the vodka slice, and the square Sicilian fried-eggplant slice with fresh mozzarella, surmounted by a very large basil leaf. But best of all is the stuffed slice, which features Italian sausage, pepperoni, potatoes, and cheese pressed between a double crust — it’s double delicious, and may identify the roots of Pizzatown in Abruzzo, where such pizzas are a specialty.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Proving how a pizzeria can anchor an entire neighborhood — in this case Carroll Gardens — Giardini is a daytime haven for hungry school kids, card-playing seniors, and shoppers dashing in for a fortifying bite. In the evenings, dating couples and families fill the space, which boasts an outdoor garden. The pizza is made with great thought and care; the grandma slice here is in the upside-down Sicilian format, with a wealth of cheese beneath the tomato sauce, and a crust so good you’d eat it by itself.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The slice shop and to-go spot from the Franks, Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, is getting its own nearby sit-down spot in September, but this original location will live on. Stick with an easy order of a slice with just cheese, pepperoni, or hot sausage and sage. Or branch out with a slice from a clam pie, cacio e pepe, or even a square Sicilian slice — whatever is available.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The Park Slope stalwart is all over the map pizza-wise, even making an approximation of deep-dish Chicago pies, and regular pies with Alfredo and vodka sauces, as if pizza were pasta. Amid the welter of pizza forms is a perfect grandma — a paradoxically square and thin slice. Splotches of mutz and torn basil leaves powerfully scent the pie.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This antique closet of a space in Crown Heights belies the young age (two or three years) of this pizzeria, but that is because it was once a much older place called Nino’s. Make a beeline for the Sicilian slice, which is thick, square, bready, greasy, and altogether wonderful — a paragon of its type unmatched in the neighborhood (though there’s another branch of Joe & Sal’s in Fort Greene.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Jeez, there must be dozens of pizzerias in the five boroughs named Tony’s. This one distinctively occupies a rather grand corner double-storefront with plenty of windows, through which the snow looks rather dramatic as it falls softly on Crown Heights. The stacked ovens turn out all the usual pies, and there’s also a sideline in jerk chicken, a neighborhood favorite. Torn into pieces, that bird goes on a slice, with some barbecue sauce striped on for extra sweetness. Hey, it’s good!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 15671 Crossbay Blvd (at 157th Ave), Howard Beach, NY 11414
description: This venerable pizzeria is a well-known pitstop for anyone heading to the Rockaways — it shines like a beacon by the side of the road, with several lines forming for its pies. Most people choose the plain slice, which is handed over right out of the oven, making it the freshest slice in town, bubbling with more cheese than is necessary, with a memorably great crust charred here and there. Down with reheated slices!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Just how many pizzerias named Luigi’s are there in the five boroughs? Plenty, we’re sure. Located in Greenwood Heights, this one (founded in 1973) functions as a sort of community center in a neighborhood increasingly uncertain how to define itself. The pizzas are especially good, with some relatively unusual toppings, including a wonderful pie with soppressata and jalapeños, fusing old and new aspects of the neighborhood.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: What could be more perfect than a plain cheese slice, fabulously rendered? That’s the main output of Family Pizza on Flatbush Avenue. The crust is thin, but manages to be soft on the top and crisp on the bottom, a miraculous stratification in such a thin-crusted slice. The sauce is memorable by having no trace of sweetness; the cheese plain as plain can be, a perfect formulation.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This delightful Sunset Park pizzeria has been taken over by Pueblans, who have mounted a griddle in the window — actually, sticking out of the window — where tlaycoyos are grilled and then topped with queso seco and salsa. The conventional pizza slices are fine, too, especially an unusual stuffed-crust pie.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Kensington establishment at the corner of Church and Coney Island Avenue has been around since the days of the original
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Open since 1966 on Kensington’s main drag, Korner is a neighborhood pizzeria par excellence, with a corner location boasting garden-style concrete tables out front for scarfing your slices, calzones, pastas, and heroes in fine weather. The inside dining room with the usual wavy-benched orange booths is equally comfortable, the walls plastered with reminiscences of Sicily. The regular cheese slice is perfect, with a lighter-than-air crust, thin coating of tomato sauce, and an extravagance of good cheese. For vegetarians, the broccoli rabe hero is recommended.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Established in 1976, San Remo offers a deep dining room favored by Ditmas Park families, and all the usual modern pies, including lasagna pizza, the everything pie, deep dish veggie (Chicago style), Buffalo chicken pizza, and vodka pie. The best, though, is the grandma, a variation on the regular Sicilian with a thinner crust, a more herbal sauce, and black pepper. It’s scrumptious.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The pizza here features a thin crust though still of the plain, old-fashioned slice sort. As in many neighborhood joints, the cheese is the thing — a lake of it, ramping up the protein component and the richness so that one slice is likely all you need for lunch. The location directly over the R train stop at Bay Ridge Avenue is an asset.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: In an iconic Stapleton location across the street from Tappen Park, Bari’s specializes in an indigenous type of Staten Island pie that features dense, dairy-driven toppings. Shown here are two representative slices: One is a pizza-fication of the Philly cheesesteak, swamped with thin-sliced steak, caramelized onions and peppers, and a Wiz-type cheese; the other attempts to mimic a pasta Alfredo in slice form. Both are rich and taste better than they look. The pizzeria is named after the capital of Puglia, the homeland of many Staten Islanders and Brooklynites.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 750 Port Richmond Ave, Staten Island, NY 10302
description: Brother’s has one of the largest ranges of pizza types the city has yet seen. This Staten Island stalwart on a busy corner — with surprisingly lush dining areas — does an amazing margherita, thick crust or thin; popular Sicilian slices; heart-shaped pies for those in love; soupy vodka pies in emulation of the style at Goodfellas, and even deep dish Chicago pies, with lots of cheese and rock-hard crust. Classic Neapolitan pies have a puffy circumferential crust and are slightly thicker than usual — this nabe loves carbs.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 1424 Avenue J (at E 15th St), Brooklyn, NY 11230
description: Though the pizza prince
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Placing it among the most ancient and venerable of early neighborhood pizzerias, which saw their heyday in the 1950s and 1960s, Pizza Wagon was founded in 1966. It possesses one of the most convivial dining rooms in Bay Ridge, and doesn’t bother with a vast range of pie choices. Thus, most slices are served still warm from the oven, and a favorite is the Sicilian, with a crisp and light crust, plenty of sweet tomato sauce, and a thick mantle of cheese. Open late.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The upside-down Sicilian is star of the show at this classic Dyker Heights pizzeria (established in the ’90s), which is more glitzy and comfortable than its brethren along New Utrecht Avenue. The slice in question is more square, thin, and crisp than most Sicilians, with the mozzarella next to the crust; the rich, thick, sweet tomato sauce on top of that; and a scatter of Parmesan on top. The garlic knots are especially good and so are the outsize, deep-fried rice balls, once again demonstrating Sicilian heritage of this excellent place.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Bay Ridge pizzeria elicits hyperbolic praise from its many fans, especially for its standard thin-crust cheese pie, with tomato sauce not too sweet, mozzarella not too rich or profuse, and a very light hand with the herbs. In fact, if I were to select a candidate for best cheese slice in Brooklyn, Espresso might win, representing a Platonic ideal of plainness.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 1758 Victory Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10314
description: Since 1960, this modest pizzeria has been regarded as the best slice shop in Staten Island. The pizza is imperially thin, with a crust that almost crackles, and the quality of the tomato sauce and cheese keep pace. This is the kind of pizza where two slices is barely enough. At Joe & Pat’s you’ll never get bored — there’s a vodka sauce pie and a fried squid pizza, too, and other so-called gourmet toppings run to to scungilli, pancetta, and artichokes. Still, the slice with cupped pepperoni is the clear neighborhood favorite.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Albanian-run pizzeria preserves the brick-oven Italian-American pizza traditions it inherited, and embroiders on them by doing a few pies with Balkan ingredients. But the traditional pies are of good quality (get slices at the counter in the righthand storefront), with a doughy crust, modest amount of tomato sauce, and cheese nicely browned on top.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located right around the corner from Kings Highway — hence the name — this grandstanding pizza parlor is especially orange in décor and delivers equally bold flavor. The bacon slice is wondrous, carpeted with smoked and crumbled pork belly, a greater quantity than you’d expect. The standard slice is of average thickness, with more cheese than usual and a little less sauce. Between 3 p.m. and 4 p.m., a tsunami of students, construction workers, and tradespeople blow in and throng the tiny shop.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Bad Boys is a classic full-service pizzeria, rolling out such sidelines as baked manicotti, pepper-and-egg heros, and fried calamari. The star of the show remains the pizzas, especially the fresh mozzarella pie with a soupçon of olive oil dribbled atop the cheese, and the square Sicilian, with a crust a little thinner and crunchier than most and a fragrant scatter of dried herbs.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Love it or hate it — L&B proffers one of the most distinctive Sicilian pizzas in town. The square slices are in the famous Brooklyn upside-down configuration, wherein the cheese is underneath and the sauce on top. Romano cheese is sprinkled above that for added salinity, and the interior of the crust is often damp and doughy though the bottom of the crust is supremely crunchy.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This pizzeria, marble counters and all, looks like the last century, and while it isn’t convenient to beachgoers, it is a favorite among locals. The round pizzas are pretty much predictable, but the square Sicilian slices a little thinner and more perfectly browned than usual. The grandma is particularly great, with alternating bands of tomato sauce and cheese.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Sam’s Pizza, in the hilly Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, is a no-nonsense pizzeria where they’re not always vying to invent new slices or attract a new audience. The place is
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located in hilly Kingsbridge and boasting a big and comfortable dining room, BPP is deluxe for a neighborhood joint. The best slice wasn’t the Neapolitan pepperoni or the Sicilian cheese, but the lasagna slice, with gobs of mellow ricotta, splotches of sweet sauce, and herb-scented ground beef. You won’t miss the noodles. For a spicy kick, try the chicken fra diavolo a la Rosa, one among many entrees served with spaghetti, ziti, or salad with garlic bread. The slogan of this delightful spot is, “The taste you always come back to,” and we will!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Tucked under the chin of Fordham University, this quintessential college hang — most famous, perhaps, for its chicken roll — has been twirling pie dough since 1985. Nothing too unusual about the cheese slice — exceedingly thin-crusted, cheese distributed unevenly, dark and sweet tomato sauce (owner Sal was born in Sicily). Scratch your initials on a wooden booth.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This ancient pizzeria retains its nostalgic, time-worn décor, including dozens of framed photographs from the last six decades. The location is iconic, in the midst of the Bronx’s Little Italy (a/k/a Belmont or Arthur Avenue). The pizza here is much better than at surrounding, snazzier pizzerias. Start with the modest cheese slice, which glistens with oils, necessitating the classic New York fold. The slice is salty, the crust nicely browned, the bone (or cornicione) almost non-existent. This constitutes one of the Bronx’s best slices, idiosyncratic and made with pride.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This two-decade-old pizzeria bills itself as “A Taste of Italy in Harlem” — and it is indeed, with an extended menu of chicken, veal, seafood, and eggplant. Most folks dash in for a slice, and the overwhelming favorite is the pepperoni, with sliced sausage runner up with profuse tomato sauce for pungency. Sicilian slices and calzones are also worth ordering.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This mainstay with a self-congratulatory name sits just east of the South Bronx. Open since 1958, it was founded at the dawn of the neighborhood pizzeria era, when the stacked pizza oven was first popularized, and the old-fashioned interior, with an order window on the street, shows it. The slices are thicker, with lusher toppings than usual, and the accommodating pizzaioli will ladle extra sauce on a slice at your request. Get the white spinach, which boasts clouds of soft ricotta and plenty of garlic.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Golden is about as bare-bones as a pizzeria can be, yet it has obviously been feeding the populace of its Mott Haven neighborhood for a good long time. The dining room is standing-only, and the counter routinely displays only one kind of slice, yet what a slice it is! Trim, nicely clotted with good cheese, not quite thin-crusted but crisp and tasty nonetheless. You can have some pepperoni thrown on top, but it’s not necessary. And, miracle of miracles, prices remain low.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Mama’s Too is one of the new crop of neighborhood pizzerias that have reconfigured their slices to be modern and innovative. (The place is related to a more conventional pizzeria on Amsterdam Avenue.) This is all to the good, you’ll realize as you survey the collection of square pies with rich crusts and atypical toppings. The pepperoni slice uses a small sausage packed tightly on the slice, weeping with paprika oil. Other pies include caramelized onion and mushroom, pear and gorgonzola, and zucchini with Kalamata olives.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Pizzaiolo Sal Malanga opened this popular Upper West Side joint in 1959 and ran it until his death in 2011. His crust remains the quintessential element — "
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Sam’s is a throwback to the ’60s, when East Harlem was one of the city’s most prominent Italian neighborhoods. The place is narrow and efficient, and turns out a bigger range of products than seems possible given the small space. The pizza crust is especially thin and crisp, and the regular slice is on the cheesy side with a big thick cornicione. Among specialty slices, the three meat (pepperoni, bacon, Italian sausages) is especially fine and greasy, and the chicken Parm slice a nice mashup.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The name says it all at this Upper West Side institution dedicated to the dairy component of the classic slice. The cheese here is so profuse, it threatens to roll off the pie. Sure, the crust is a bit doughy and pale, and the sauce recedes into the background. But gradually as you eat it, you’ll realize the other components have been formulated so you can better worship the molten cheese.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 421 Amsterdam Ave (at W 80th St), New York, NY 10024
description: This mini chain, reportedly founded by disciples of Greenpoint’s Paulie Gee (who is actually name-checked on the menu) are profusely topped, sometimes with unusual ingredients like honey, cherry peppers, and barbecue sauce, ending up in thin-crust, slices that are often spicy and somewhat soupy.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The pizzas here are bakery style and come out of the oven in sheets at various times of the day. Get there at the right time and enjoy a Sicilian-style slice heavily topped with cheese. This is pizza nirvana in the context of a bakery rather than a pizzeria. Other types of pie have become available as the pizza business here has expanded.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located in a strip shopping center just off the Whitestone Expressway where cars rush by on the way to LaGuardia in one direction and the Bronx in the other, Amore is a paragon of parking lot pizza, and much better than it needs to be. The pies are bigger and more lush than usual, meaning that individual slices are bigger, too. And the luxuriance of cheese means that the warm slice will flop around like a fish in your hand. That’s Amore!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: A mural of Venice graces one wall of this venerable Upper East Side pizzeria — with Superman flying overhead, looking for criminals. If you want to feel like you’re sitting in a real restaurant while scarfing your two slices and a soft drink, this is your place. And the quality of the pies makes it a destination spot, too. Our favorite is the grandma slice: In the square format, it displays cheese-on-the-bottom pizza-architecture, with splotches of herby sauce on top.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Who can resist the white slice at the former Astoria Hot Pizza, with its masses of ricotta and mozzarella on an white crust? The chicken slice is another favorite: a diced cutlet, tasting fresh from the fryer, scattered across what would otherwise be a regular cheese slice. It’s like a deconstructed chicken cutlet Parm hero. This place shares space with a Middle Eastern grocery store, which allows an unusual latitude in the selection of beverages.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Hell’s Kitchen pizzeria has been open over half a century, and feels reminiscent of the old neighborhood with its rustic premises and hand-scrawled menu. The cheese slice is very thin-crusted without being crunchy, and is notable for its large quantity of cheese. And though alternate slices are not on display, there is an aggressive list of add ons that run to anchovies, fresh garlic, olives, and bacon.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This pizzeria not far from the Broadway theaters treats its output like a dramatic event. Dating from 1994, it flaunts a long glass counter with a ridiculous number of pie choices, including the meat lover’s pie that features sausage, bacon, and pepperoni. Other sporadically available pies deploy Portuguese chorizo, Philly cheesesteak, lemony chicken Francese, and Tex-Mex jalapeños with seasoned ground beef.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Sam’s is a throwback pizzeria in a neighborhood where Spanish is now the lingua franca. It’s an old time father-and-son operation, founded in 1957, that turns out to have excellent pizza, especially the hyper-thick Sicilian slices, with an unusually pungent tomato sauce possessing a touch of sweetness, and better-than-average cheese. Betcha can’t eat two!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Gianni’s is a classic 1980 Jackson Heights pizzeria, heavy on the Sicilian influences, with an ambitious menu, but a premises that says “pizzeria” rather than “restaurant.” There’s a nice little backyard, and the thing to not miss is the Sicilian slice. The bottom side of the crust is brown and crisp, the crumb light as air, the sauce on the sweet side, and the cheese tumbles over the side like a waterfall.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Clad in green marble, this pizzeria directly across the street from Grand Central is downright elegant. The interior gleams and the patrons are often well-dressed. Our favorite is the lasagna slice, which emulates a serving of lasagna with its rich sauce, ground beef, and ricotta cheese, which plays second fiddle to lots of mozzarella.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Surrounded by Northern Chinese restaurants, Daro’s is tasked with fulfilling two pressing neighborhood needs: pizza and fried chicken. Here it seems the pizza predated the bird, because the list of pies is far more sophisticated than the chicken menu. A case in point is the grandma slice, thin-crusted and utilizing fresh mozzarella, premium tomato sauce, and fresh basil — an herb not easy to find in these parts. Hot heroes are another strong point, especially the iconic egg and peppers.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This especially comfortable pizzeria is part of a Manhattan mini-chain, with a deep dark interior kept cool in sweltering weather, and mounts an enticing display of by-the-slice pies to lure passers-by. Of several sampled, the one topped with pepperoni and canned jalapeños was the most enthralling, mouth-tingling in the best possible way.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, New York, New York 10119
description: Roberta’s new Italian restaurant, with a roof deck nonetheless, is found off an alleyway in the new Penn One complex. Tucked into the ground floor space is the Roberta’s version of a neighborhood pizzeria, concocting five or six pies from the super creative to the straight-ahead slice. The difference? A wood-burning oven and puffier crust, charred in spots.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Proving that even today neighborhood pizzerias are opening up, Highline appeared not long ago on the edge of Hudson Yards, peddling a menu of predictable slices with a few new twists. The pale crust is distinguished, and one of the best uses is in a pie topped with cubed chicken cutlet and fresh ripe tomato. This place floods with construction workers from nearby high-rises in the post-noon period.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located directly southwest of Penn Station since 1964, NY Pizza Suprema is undoubtedly one of the most celebrated neighborhood pizzerias in Manhattan. The lavish display of pies under glass right inside the front entrance provides a beguiling dilemma, but I generally spring for any of the Sicilian slices, which have a bit of oil in the dough and are thus crunchier than most. The sausage Sicilian is particularly dope, miring shavings of good fennel sausage in a profuse floe of cheese.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 84-02 Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, New York 11373
description: Exploring new territory in the demimonde of slice pizza, El Mercadito sends the genre in a Mexican direction, with a selection of taco fillings as pie toppings, in addition to a roster of more conventional slices, just off the avenue in a mini shopping mall. Putting a cheese-filled chile relleno on top of a slice is a brilliant move and one that deserves to be commended.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 4001 Queens Blvd (40th st and Queens Blvd), Sunnyside, NY 11104
description: Conveniently located right on Sunnyside’s main drag on a stop on the 7 train right overhead. this tiny pizzeria has a charmingly cramped layout, and a small counter under an awning right on the street that permits a cinematic enjoyment of your slice. Those slices show Sicilian influences, partly via the sesame seeds sprinkled on some slices, including a wonderful buffalo chicken slice that also has some barbecue sauce squirted on it.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Founded in 1997, this Chelsea mainstay seems far older. The regular slice is especially tomatoey and slightly salty, best enjoyed as part of the lunch special (two slices and a can of soda). On the other hand, then you’d miss the dense white broccoli slice, which features cloudy masses of ricotta and mozzarella. Seating is limited to a gleaming metal counter and are those Roy Lichtenstein prints on the walls? He once lived nearby.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 688 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10010
description: This new Flower District spot doesn’t look like much from the outside, yet turns out thoughtfully topped slices with a thin crisp crust and cheese and sauce that recede into the background — in a good way. A bacon and pepperoni slice is a case in point, with the sausage rounds submerged in cheese. They provide explosions of flavor, as the crumbled bacon on top dominates with its smoky saltiness. One slice is rich enough to constitute a full meal.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Woodside pizzeria of ancient vintage always had a larger menu than most. On top of the regular pies, there are pastas, heroes, salads, steaks and chops, and belt-busting, all-in Italian dinners. But in addition, the place now serves Mexican food, so that you can have guac and chips alongside your Sicilian slice. The cemitas (round Pueblan sandwiches) have become neighborhood favorites. Hopefully, the Mexican and Italian menus will begin fusing, and we can expect a Mexican pizza strewn with chiles and cactus strips, or maybe chipotle chicken, in the future.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Debuting in 1984 and occupying a distinctive corner location in Sunnyside, Marabella is proud of its Sicilian roots, as evidenced by the choice of art and maps on the walls. The ovens stand right inside the front door to make it easy to dash in and out for a slice. You should look no further than the fine grandma slice, which is square and thin-crusted, sporting fresh mozzarella and thick, sweet tomato sauce. Unique to Marabella are sandwiches (the pizzeria calls focaccia) made by splitting a thick wedge of pizza and piling it with chicken Parm and other fillings.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The components of the so-called Greek slice are deceptively simple; a very crisp square crust that crackles rather than squishes, with perhaps a pinch of sugar in the dough, assorted olives both black and green, the collection varying by day, sweet baby plum tomatoes cut in half, plain tomato sauce, basil leaves, and maybe the occasional mince of fresh garlic. You won’t miss the cheese in the novel, crave-able slice.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: I like pizzerias squished into tiny spaces, where the ovens dominated the visual landscape and a single employee serves as pie wrangler and cashier. Just down the block from an important subway stop, Village Pizza is just such a place, with a surprisingly large collection of slices for its cramped premises. The Buffalo chicken is one the best, featuring a cut-up chicken cutlet and tart sauce that delivers a spicy and vinegary tang. Some say this slice was invented by pizzerias trying to get in on the football-party delivery action without actually doing wings.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The stylish pizzeria (the name means “Little Moon”) is on the verge of becoming an actual restaurant, but the emphasis remains staunchly on some excellent pies, with a sauce perhaps a little sweeter than usual. The margherita is a round, thin-crust pie with fresh mozzarella and crushed tomatoes here and there, creating a prodigious mouth wallop. A larger than usual roster of apps, subs, hamburgers, heros, and cheesesteaks provide enhanced dinner options.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located on the northern reaches of Manhattan Avenue, Triangolo is one of Greenpoint’s most distinguished neighborhood parlors. An order on a recent visit was an extra-thick slice with sauce and cheese, dotted with bacon, pepperoni, and ground beef. The cheese and spinach stromboli, with a particularly crisp crust, was also exemplary. Dig the lettering on the neon sign outside, and don’t miss the cryptic Steven Seagal shrine.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: King of the Manhattan neighborhood pizza parlor, Joe’s offers a slice magnificent in its plainness, appreciated by generations of New Yorkers and visitors. No frou-frou here, just a well-pureed sauce and just enough cheese — but not too much — and one of the city’s most perfect crusts. On the other hand, for just a bit more you can get the fresh mozzarella slice, with little annealed gobs of cheese. The best-selling slice, according to a counter guy I talked to, is the pepperoni. Miraculously, new branches of this place near Union Square, Times Square, and in Williamsburg have not diminished its brilliance.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Yes, the swells head further down Greenpoint Avenue for Paulie Gee’s, a wood-oven place with some weird and sometimes spectacular pies. Franklin is conveniently located just across the street from the historic Pencil Factory bar, so that you can see beer fans knocking off a slice or two before scampering across the street. Featuring both ricotta and mozzarella, the broccoli slice is a particular fave, and the drinkers all know that one constitutes a perfectly balanced meal.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 83 Saint Marks Pl (at 1st Ave.), New York, NY 10003
description: Generations of rock musicians, poets, and painters have cheaply feasted — often late into the night — at Stromboli, located at the crossroads of St. Marks and First Avenue in the East Village. The crust is thin, the deep red sauce with more than a touch of sweetness, and the cheese moderately applied, and late in evening, clubgoers mill around on the sidewalks gobbling down their slices.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 177 Spring St (at Thompson St), New York, NY 10012
description: Famous Ben’s was founded in 1979 and remains Soho’s bastion of the Sicilian slice. Most interesting, perhaps, are the versions of the classic square pie that pre-date the cheese-and-tomato-sauced square so famous at nearly every neighborhood pizza parlor. The Palermo sliced (aka sfincione) is topped with onions, tomato sauce, and bread crumbs — but no cheese.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Proving that old-style neighborhood pizzerias are not a bygone phenomenon, Rosalia’s opened not long ago in Forest Hills, with the same owner as Luzzo’s in the East Village and bygone Gansevoort Market. You can tell the proprietor is a Staten Islander the minute you bite into the spinach and artichoke slice, with little hills of melting ricotta, and a soupy greenish sauce. In Staten Island, the semi-liquid slice is king.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: There are now multiple locations of this 1987 pizzeria that seeks to incorporate Cajun influences into the pizza canon. The East Village location is pretty much the flagship these days, and the slices are still named after late-20th century
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 375 Canal St (at West Broadway), New York, NY 10013
description: — a first Manhattan branch of an Avenue X pizzeria that attracted
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This modest neighborhood spot has an attached dining room, which means even at peak hours you don’t have to eat your slice standing up. The slogan is, “Where every slice is a journey to Italy,” though this is about as American as pizza gets. The classic margherita is really just an amped up cheese slice, but it is delicious with its fresh mozzarella and sprightly tomato sauce.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This downtown Forest Hills fixture goes all the way back to 1960, but underwent a hiatus early in this century. Now it’s back and better than ever, offering a windowed dining room and the usual rich profusion of slice choices. A fave is the grandma slice: a crisp, square crust with an impressive slab of mozzarella, a slice of fresh tomato, and strips of roasted red pepper, making for an unusual slice that tastes like an Italian street fair.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 113 Mulberry St (btwn Canal and Hester), New York, NY 10013
description: This newish Little Italy pizzeria more or less presents itself as a cocktail lounge — yet it serves slices and behaves in many respects as a neighborhood pizzeria. The Neapolitan slices tend to be a bit heavy and browned, and often display atypical toppings.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This revolutionary neighborhood pizzeria deep in the Lower East Side is a game changer where slices are concerned. For a traditional pizzeria, more care is taken than usual — the flour is freshly milled in the basement, for Pete’s sake. Long lines form, and slices are richer and thinner crusted than most. Sicilian slices and grandma slices are also available. This is a unique and exciting neighborhood pizzeria.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Holding down an incredibly expensive corner location in Tribeca, Dona Bella ("Beautiful Lady") puts an almost surreal amount of energy into its eye-socking window display. The crusts on the Neapolitan slices are a little thicker than usual, the toppings applied with a thick hand. A case in point is the wonderful mushroom slice, to which a great heap of ‘shrooms has been applied, and plenty of cheese, too. The round fresh mozzarella pie is also great, with big splotches of sweet tomato sauce.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This 1967 neighborhood pizzeria is more elegant than most, with views out the big picture windows (which open in fine weather) and good wine and beer served, too. The eggplant slice features crisp, crumbed slices of vegetable, hillocks of ricotta, and a thin crust that invites you to eat the thing with a knife and fork. And nobody will laugh at you if you do.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: All Little Italy franchises are not the same. In fact, some are superb while others awful, with doughy crusts and lifeless tomato sauces. The City Hall branch is one of the great ones, and you can tell the minute you step inside and see the elated diners. A favorite slice is the carbonara, which features two kinds of cheese along with shards of prosciutto, making it one of the city’s few pies to utilize that cold-cut cooked.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: There’s a new branch drawing lines at lunchtime in the West Village, but I still prefer the original in the shadow of the BQE in an obscure corner of Williamsburg. If you can get a cheese slice right out of the oven, grab it! Otherwise, slices are prepared ahead, adding, say burrata to a once-baked slice. (Inn some ways, it’s perhaps a signature topping.)  Italian pastries are also excellent here.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Open in the shadow of the M and J tracks, this parlor is young in pizzeria years, but excels at all the classic pies and hero sandwiches. Some of the best things on the menu, though, show a Latin bent. For example, the miniature pie called an onion pizzette is about as close as you can get to a real Buenos Aires fugazetta. Other favorites include a spinach-ricotta slice that seems positively healthy, and an idiosyncratic take on a hot dog, wrapping it in pizza dough with melted cheese. Delicious!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: How does a simple independent slice joint stay in business in the Wall Street area? By serving some of the best pizza in town in a somewhat shabby and abject location a few steps below street level. Nevertheless, this is a frequently recommended favorite among brokers, clerks, digital journalists, and non-profit wonks who labor in the neighborhood. The fresh mozzarella slice is especially enticing, with splotches of sweet herby tomato sauce, great mozzarella that doesn’t go all soggy, and a memorably crisp, browned crust.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This antediluvian Bushwick pizzeria that resides above the Dekalb stop on the L dates back to the days when this was an Italian neighborhood and its sausage roll was fabled. In terms of pizza, go for the Sicilian slice. It's thick and square and brown as a beetle, with little rivulets of sauce and cheese and a generous sprinkling of dried Romano for extra saltiness and flavor. It's worth traveling from another borough to try!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This pizzeria, shuttered for nearly a year by
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Since the 1970s, when Bushwick was still an Italian stronghold, Tony’s Pizza has been turning out near-perfect pies on Knickerbocker Avenue, a stone’s throw from Maria Hernandez Park. The slice is austere in its structure: the crust pale and thinner than most, but crisp; the sauce mild and only slightly sweet; the better-than-average cheese strewn with a generous hand. Devotees also extol the hot hero sandwiches, potato-lovers pie, and fried calamari.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located in an obscure corner of downtown Brooklyn, Little Pizza is the cutest pizzeria around, with outdoor seating along the sidewalk and a pretty flower-tile motif inside. The thin-crust slices often stray from the typical, with sausage, tomatoes, hot cherry peppers, and mozzarella, and the margherita adds a good quantity of pecorino to the usual fresh mozzarella.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: What pizza parlor boasts outdoor seating in the back? This one in downtown Brooklyn does, and also a large dining room perfect for accommodating lunchtime crowds. The supreme slice is the one to get, with an unusually thin crust for a fresh mozzarella slice, browned more than most and hence crisp. The cheese is cooked a little more, too. This is an atypical take on a classic slice, and six or seven more slices are commonly available at any given time. Especially if you’re a plain-cheese orderer, ask for a lime to spray over the slice.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Making fun of the Famous Ray's and its imitators, Not Ray's is a neighborhood pizza parlor in a memorable, wedge-shaped space right on Fulton Street. The slice has a narrow cornicione, the cheese is modestly applied, and the tomato sauce piquant and somewhat sweet. The slice is a little gloppier than usual and a molten cheese-sauce hybrid spills over the sides. Dying for novelty? Try the Buffalo chicken or Caesar salad pies.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Ocean Hill establishment is a branch of a long-running Canarsie pizzeria that’s been in the D’Arpa family since 1968, now being run by a third generation. Like the sign outside says, the mini-chain’s specialty is the Sicilian slice, and you’ve never tasted better. The bread is thick and bouncy, but paradoxically light-textured, and the sauce in the typical Sicilian style is a little on the sweet side. In addition, there’s a strong taste of oregano, which may or may not be due to the Greek origin of many Sicilians. Other specialties include a delicious, sesame-seeded ground beef stromboli, pepperoni pinwheels, and meatball rolls.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 192 Union St (at Henry St), Brooklyn, NY 11231
description: The rarest of the pizza slice types in the city are those that come from old-fashioned Italian bakeries like Mazzola. It recently moved around the corner into newer digs, but that didn’t interfere with the excellence of its square bakery pies. Thin for a Sicilian slice, these taste of freshly baked bread, the tomato sauce is on the sweet side, and there is no stinting on the cheese. One is a meal, and extra points if you get a slice from a pie just out of the oven.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The pizzas here are damn good, with a slightly thicker crust than usual, and some fairly creative toppings. The margarita slice is memorable, pooled with fresh mozzarella and dotted with herbs, while the lasagna slice mimics that casserole with an insane amount of delicately seasoned ground beef and wads of fresh ricotta.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Champion is a mini-chain with a newish branch in Bed-Stuy. Sold by the slice, most of the pizzas are square, the crusts relatively thin, and done to a dark brown. Toppings are innovative, too, including one slice that features alternate bands of green pesto and red tomato sauce, like a Morris Lewis painting in the Museum of Modern Art.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This lively pizzeria with some nifty murals has been a mainstay of 5th Avenue in the Slope since 1987. The regular slice boasts a thicker and crisper crust than usual, and many patrons go for the extensive collection of novelties — such as the Buffalo chicken slice, the vodka slice, and the square Sicilian fried-eggplant slice with fresh mozzarella, surmounted by a very large basil leaf. But best of all is the stuffed slice, which features Italian sausage, pepperoni, potatoes, and cheese pressed between a double crust — it’s double delicious, and may identify the roots of Pizzatown in Abruzzo, where such pizzas are a specialty.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Proving how a pizzeria can anchor an entire neighborhood — in this case Carroll Gardens — Giardini is a daytime haven for hungry school kids, card-playing seniors, and shoppers dashing in for a fortifying bite. In the evenings, dating couples and families fill the space, which boasts an outdoor garden. The pizza is made with great thought and care; the grandma slice here is in the upside-down Sicilian format, with a wealth of cheese beneath the tomato sauce, and a crust so good you’d eat it by itself.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The slice shop and to-go spot from the Franks, Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, is getting its own nearby sit-down spot in September, but this original location will live on. Stick with an easy order of a slice with just cheese, pepperoni, or hot sausage and sage. Or branch out with a slice from a clam pie, cacio e pepe, or even a square Sicilian slice — whatever is available.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The Park Slope stalwart is all over the map pizza-wise, even making an approximation of deep-dish Chicago pies, and regular pies with Alfredo and vodka sauces, as if pizza were pasta. Amid the welter of pizza forms is a perfect grandma — a paradoxically square and thin slice. Splotches of mutz and torn basil leaves powerfully scent the pie.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This antique closet of a space in Crown Heights belies the young age (two or three years) of this pizzeria, but that is because it was once a much older place called Nino’s. Make a beeline for the Sicilian slice, which is thick, square, bready, greasy, and altogether wonderful — a paragon of its type unmatched in the neighborhood (though there’s another branch of Joe & Sal’s in Fort Greene.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Jeez, there must be dozens of pizzerias in the five boroughs named Tony’s. This one distinctively occupies a rather grand corner double-storefront with plenty of windows, through which the snow looks rather dramatic as it falls softly on Crown Heights. The stacked ovens turn out all the usual pies, and there’s also a sideline in jerk chicken, a neighborhood favorite. Torn into pieces, that bird goes on a slice, with some barbecue sauce striped on for extra sweetness. Hey, it’s good!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 15671 Crossbay Blvd (at 157th Ave), Howard Beach, NY 11414
description: This venerable pizzeria is a well-known pitstop for anyone heading to the Rockaways — it shines like a beacon by the side of the road, with several lines forming for its pies. Most people choose the plain slice, which is handed over right out of the oven, making it the freshest slice in town, bubbling with more cheese than is necessary, with a memorably great crust charred here and there. Down with reheated slices!
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Just how many pizzerias named Luigi’s are there in the five boroughs? Plenty, we’re sure. Located in Greenwood Heights, this one (founded in 1973) functions as a sort of community center in a neighborhood increasingly uncertain how to define itself. The pizzas are especially good, with some relatively unusual toppings, including a wonderful pie with soppressata and jalapeños, fusing old and new aspects of the neighborhood.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: What could be more perfect than a plain cheese slice, fabulously rendered? That’s the main output of Family Pizza on Flatbush Avenue. The crust is thin, but manages to be soft on the top and crisp on the bottom, a miraculous stratification in such a thin-crusted slice. The sauce is memorable by having no trace of sweetness; the cheese plain as plain can be, a perfect formulation.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This delightful Sunset Park pizzeria has been taken over by Pueblans, who have mounted a griddle in the window — actually, sticking out of the window — where tlaycoyos are grilled and then topped with queso seco and salsa. The conventional pizza slices are fine, too, especially an unusual stuffed-crust pie.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Kensington establishment at the corner of Church and Coney Island Avenue has been around since the days of the original
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Open since 1966 on Kensington’s main drag, Korner is a neighborhood pizzeria par excellence, with a corner location boasting garden-style concrete tables out front for scarfing your slices, calzones, pastas, and heroes in fine weather. The inside dining room with the usual wavy-benched orange booths is equally comfortable, the walls plastered with reminiscences of Sicily. The regular cheese slice is perfect, with a lighter-than-air crust, thin coating of tomato sauce, and an extravagance of good cheese. For vegetarians, the broccoli rabe hero is recommended.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Established in 1976, San Remo offers a deep dining room favored by Ditmas Park families, and all the usual modern pies, including lasagna pizza, the everything pie, deep dish veggie (Chicago style), Buffalo chicken pizza, and vodka pie. The best, though, is the grandma, a variation on the regular Sicilian with a thinner crust, a more herbal sauce, and black pepper. It’s scrumptious.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The pizza here features a thin crust though still of the plain, old-fashioned slice sort. As in many neighborhood joints, the cheese is the thing — a lake of it, ramping up the protein component and the richness so that one slice is likely all you need for lunch. The location directly over the R train stop at Bay Ridge Avenue is an asset.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: In an iconic Stapleton location across the street from Tappen Park, Bari’s specializes in an indigenous type of Staten Island pie that features dense, dairy-driven toppings. Shown here are two representative slices: One is a pizza-fication of the Philly cheesesteak, swamped with thin-sliced steak, caramelized onions and peppers, and a Wiz-type cheese; the other attempts to mimic a pasta Alfredo in slice form. Both are rich and taste better than they look. The pizzeria is named after the capital of Puglia, the homeland of many Staten Islanders and Brooklynites.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 750 Port Richmond Ave, Staten Island, NY 10302
description: Brother’s has one of the largest ranges of pizza types the city has yet seen. This Staten Island stalwart on a busy corner — with surprisingly lush dining areas — does an amazing margherita, thick crust or thin; popular Sicilian slices; heart-shaped pies for those in love; soupy vodka pies in emulation of the style at Goodfellas, and even deep dish Chicago pies, with lots of cheese and rock-hard crust. Classic Neapolitan pies have a puffy circumferential crust and are slightly thicker than usual — this nabe loves carbs.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 1424 Avenue J (at E 15th St), Brooklyn, NY 11230
description: Though the pizza prince
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Placing it among the most ancient and venerable of early neighborhood pizzerias, which saw their heyday in the 1950s and 1960s, Pizza Wagon was founded in 1966. It possesses one of the most convivial dining rooms in Bay Ridge, and doesn’t bother with a vast range of pie choices. Thus, most slices are served still warm from the oven, and a favorite is the Sicilian, with a crisp and light crust, plenty of sweet tomato sauce, and a thick mantle of cheese. Open late.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: The upside-down Sicilian is star of the show at this classic Dyker Heights pizzeria (established in the ’90s), which is more glitzy and comfortable than its brethren along New Utrecht Avenue. The slice in question is more square, thin, and crisp than most Sicilians, with the mozzarella next to the crust; the rich, thick, sweet tomato sauce on top of that; and a scatter of Parmesan on top. The garlic knots are especially good and so are the outsize, deep-fried rice balls, once again demonstrating Sicilian heritage of this excellent place.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Bay Ridge pizzeria elicits hyperbolic praise from its many fans, especially for its standard thin-crust cheese pie, with tomato sauce not too sweet, mozzarella not too rich or profuse, and a very light hand with the herbs. In fact, if I were to select a candidate for best cheese slice in Brooklyn, Espresso might win, representing a Platonic ideal of plainness.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

address: 1758 Victory Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10314
description: Since 1960, this modest pizzeria has been regarded as the best slice shop in Staten Island. The pizza is imperially thin, with a crust that almost crackles, and the quality of the tomato sauce and cheese keep pace. This is the kind of pizza where two slices is barely enough. At Joe & Pat’s you’ll never get bored — there’s a vodka sauce pie and a fried squid pizza, too, and other so-called gourmet toppings run to to scungilli, pancetta, and artichokes. Still, the slice with cupped pepperoni is the clear neighborhood favorite.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This Albanian-run pizzeria preserves the brick-oven Italian-American pizza traditions it inherited, and embroiders on them by doing a few pies with Balkan ingredients. But the traditional pies are of good quality (get slices at the counter in the righthand storefront), with a doughy crust, modest amount of tomato sauce, and cheese nicely browned on top.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Located right around the corner from Kings Highway — hence the name — this grandstanding pizza parlor is especially orange in décor and delivers equally bold flavor. The bacon slice is wondrous, carpeted with smoked and crumbled pork belly, a greater quantity than you’d expect. The standard slice is of average thickness, with more cheese than usual and a little less sauce. Between 3 p.m. and 4 p.m., a tsunami of students, construction workers, and tradespeople blow in and throng the tiny shop.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Bad Boys is a classic full-service pizzeria, rolling out such sidelines as baked manicotti, pepper-and-egg heros, and fried calamari. The star of the show remains the pizzas, especially the fresh mozzarella pie with a soupçon of olive oil dribbled atop the cheese, and the square Sicilian, with a crust a little thinner and crunchier than most and a fragrant scatter of dried herbs.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: Love it or hate it — L&B proffers one of the most distinctive Sicilian pizzas in town. The square slices are in the famous Brooklyn upside-down configuration, wherein the cheese is underneath and the sauce on top. Romano cheese is sprinkled above that for added salinity, and the interior of the crust is often damp and doughy though the bottom of the crust is supremely crunchy.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY

description: This pizzeria, marble counters and all, looks like the last century, and while it isn’t convenient to beachgoers, it is a favorite among locals. The round pizzas are pretty much predictable, but the square Sicilian slices a little thinner and more perfectly browned than usual. The grandma is particularly great, with alternating bands of tomato sauce and cheese.
site_title: The Eater List of New York City Slices - Eater NY
